p: Traditionally, Koreans consume large quantities of soybeans and soy-containing foods to overcome the risk of protein deficiency caused by a predominantly rice-based diet, which may be responsible for the low incidence of hormone-related diseases, such as breast and prostate cancer [ 6]. Global soybean consumption steadily increased at an average annual rate of 4%, and the annual soybean consumption in Korea increased from 4.4 kg per capita in 1965 to 8.5 kg per capita in 2003 [ 7]. The main non-fermented soybean foods consumed in Korea are soy milk, tofu, and bean sprouts. Fermented foods include soy sauce, miso, and chungkukjang [ 8].
